When a woman dies due to any burns or bodily injury and it occurs within seven years of her marriage it can fall under Section 304B.
If it is established that there was a demand for dowry whether before or after the marriage and this demand led to the death of the woman.
Cruelty or Harassment: When a woman is subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband or his relatives with the intention of coercing her or her relatives to meet dowry demands.
There is a legal presumption that the death of a woman within seven years of her marriage caused by burns or bodily injury is a dowry death unless proven otherwise.

A party to a civil lawsuit presents documentary evidence to support their claims, and the admissibility of the documents is determined under the Act.

In a case involving electronic evidence, such as text messages or emails, the Act is used to determine their admissibility.

In child custody disputes, evidence is presented to determine the child's best interests, and the Act is used to assess the admissibility of such evidence.
In cases related to domestic violence, the Act is applied to evaluate the admissibility of evidence, including medical records and witness statements.
In cases involving maintenance or alimony, evidence of the financial status of the parties is presented and assessed under the Act.

In cases related to property disputes, the Act is applied to assess the admissibility of documents, deeds, and other evidence of property ownership.
In disputes involving sale or lease agreements, the Act is used to determine the admissibility of the agreements and related evidence.
In cases related to the breach of contract, the Act is used to evaluate the admissibility of written and oral evidence of the contract.
In cases of fraud or misrepresentation, evidence is presented to establish the wrongdoing, and the Act is applied to determine admissibility.

A Parsi couple residing in India wants to solemnize their Parsi marriage with all the legal formalities under the Act.

A Parsi individual marries a non-Parsi, and the Act is applied to govern the registration of their Parsi marriage.

A Parsi marriage is annulled under the Act, and the legal process is followed.

A Parsi individual intends to marry someone from a different Parsi custom, and the Act is used to govern the registration of their marriage.

Disputes regarding alimony, maintenance, or division of marital property arise during divorce proceedings.
A spouse alleges adultery, desertion, or conversion to another religion as grounds for divorce, and the Family Courts Act addresses the matter.
A couple seeks a judicial separation under the Act to live apart without formally divorcing.
Parents contest child custody and visitation rights, and the Family Courts Act determines custody arrangements.
Disputes arise over child support, education, and other expenses for the children, and the Act governs these matters.

A dispute arises between parents and grandparents regarding the guardianship and custody of a child.
An Indian citizen residing abroad wishes to get married to another Indian citizen abroad and seeks to register their marriage under the Foreign Marriage Act.
An Indian citizen residing abroad wishes to marry a foreign national while abroad and have the marriage registered under the act.
Indian expatriates living outside India plan to have their children married abroad and registered under the Foreign Marriage Act.
An Indian couple residing abroad wishes to solemnize and register their marriage in a foreign country under the act.
Indian citizens residing in different foreign countries wish to marry, and they opt to have their marriage registered under the act.
An Indian citizen gets married abroad and returns to India, wanting to have their foreign marriage registered under the act.
Indian citizens marry abroad but want to register their marriage with Indian authorities to establish their marital status in India.

An Indian citizen marries abroad but wants to change their marital status in official Indian documents, such as the passport.
Indian citizens residing abroad wish to register the birth of their child born abroad, whose parents' marriage was registered under the act.
Indian citizens want to have the birth of their child abroad recognized in India, following the registration of their marriage under the act.
